Dear Mr. Fernandez:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
February 7, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
ISEP. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or ISEP citation.
 Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Jessica VandenHeuvel, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
Two of eight files reviewed contained licensing renewal reports indicating that the
renewal application was not provided to the foster family at least 60 days prior to the
license expiration.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
One of eight files reviewed documented that the family was not practicing
emergency procedures, as required, yet the family was found to be in full
compliance with all rules and no CAP was required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as
is indicated, based on the information received, but not later
than 7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
One of six special evaluations reviewed documented that the investigation was not
initiated within 7 calendar days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
4

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
Three of six special evaluations reviewed were completed outside of the 45-day
requirements, yet the file did not contain a 45-day letter.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent then the
reason why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with
a relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R
400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s
age, appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand,
which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as to
why the change is necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
(h) The child’s new location and address.
Two of six open foster care files reviewed where a youth changed placement lacked
the information required in subsection (a) through (h) which would have been
captured in an action summary (DHS-69).
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of
the following information:
5

(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of
the change, except when prior notification would
jeopardize the child’s care or safety. If prior notice
is not provided, then the agency shall notify the
foster parent, at the time of the change, why prior
notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning
the change in placement.
Three of six open foster care files reviewed where a youth changed placement
lacked notification in writing to the foster parent as required.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment
for the foster child and the foster family, including
information about siblings who do not reside in the foster
home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
Five or eight open foster care files reviewed lacked the initial placement outline
(DHS-3307) covering the required information in subsections (a) through (i).
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical
care.
6

One of eight open foster care files reviewed lacked documentation the caregiver was
provided with authorization to provide routine and emergency medical care.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—Previous Citation FOM 801
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of three independent living files reviewed lacked documentation the agency
provided a program statement to the youth prior to placement in independent living.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
One of three independent living files reviewed lacked documentation the agency
provided policies and procedures to the youth prior to placement in independent
living.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
One of three independent living files reviewed lacked documentation for the rationale
for selection of independent living for the youth as the most appropriate placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
7

One of three independent living files reviewed lacked development of an
independent living contract with the youth until two months after the youth entered
into independent living.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.19 Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Nine of eleven open files reviewed lacked the required signatures on the case
service plans.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—Previous Citation ISEP 6.33
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
ISEP 6.24 Visits, Between Siblings
(a) DHHS shall ensure that children in foster care who have
siblings in custody with whom they are not placed shall have
at least monthly visits with their siblings who are placed
elsewhere in DHHS foster care custody. Exceptions to this
requirement are cases in which:
(1) the visit may be harmful to one or more of the siblings;
(2) the sibling is placed out of state in compliance with the
Interstate Compact on Placement of Children;
(3) the distance between the children's placements is more
than 50 miles and the child is placed with a relative; or
(4) one of the siblings is above the age of 16 and refuses
such visits.
(b) All exceptions and all reasonable steps taken to assure that
visits take place shall be documented in the case file.
One of five open foster care files reviewed where siblings were not placed together,
the monthly sibling visits were not occurring each month as required.
ISEP 6.22 Visits, Worker-Parent
(2) for each subsequent month, at least one face-to-face contact
with each parent and phone contact as needed, with at least on
8

contact in each three-month period occurring in the parent’s
place of residence.
Four of six open foster care case files with the goal of reunification reviewed lacked
documentation of the required worker-parent contact each month.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Policy violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Policy requirements except for the
following:
FOM 722-8C Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement
Signatures
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker,
supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and
older and in the case of placement agency foster care cases,
the local DHS office designee.
Six of eight open foster care files lacked the foster parent signature on the parent
agency treatment plan in a timely manner.
FOM 722-06H Caseworker Contacts
The primary caseworker must have face-to-face contact with
each child as indicated below.
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement
Change
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with each child in the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement change.
The first face-to-face contact must take place within five
business days of the date of removal or placement
change.
9

One of eleven open case files reviewed lacked documentation of at least one
face-to-face within the first five business days of the date of placement as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2018 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/22/18.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Types and Timeframes
FTMs must occur within the required time frames.
Two of eleven files reviewed lacked documentation that a Case Plan
Development/Reassessment Family Team Meeting was completed as required.
One of eleven foster care files reviewed lacked the required DHS 1105 Activity
Report uploaded into MiSACWIS as required.
Two of four files reviewed requiring a semi-annual transition plan family team
meeting, lacked documentation they occurred every six months as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2018 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/22/18.
FOM 722-9 Foster Care- Updated Service Plan
Supervisory Approval
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
10

Two of nine open case files reviewed where an updated service plans was
completed, was not approved within 14 days by the supervisor.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2018 Renewal Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/22/18.
FOM 801 Health Services for Children in Foster Care
Medical Passport requirements.
Five of eleven open case files reviewed lacked the medical passport being
completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—Previous Citation ISEP 6.49
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
FOM 722-3B Relative Engagement and Placement
3130A Obtaining Required Information: Caseworkers must
attempt to obtain the required information for each segment of
the home study by asking questions of the prospective
caregiver and other information sources. Caseworkers cannot
rely solely on the caregiver’s self-report; all members of the
household, including children, must be interviewed.
Additionally, the caseworker’s observations must be included
as part of the final recommendation.
One of one Relative home study reviewed noted the relative had criminal history
and had not yet received police reports or central registry results from out of
country.
FOM 722-3B Relative Engagement and Placement
Notification Process: Caseworkers must pursue the identifica-
tion and notification of relatives and document the initial and
ongoing efforts in the investigation report and each case
service plan.
11

Two of eleven open case files reviewed lacked documentation of the agency’s
efforts to purse the identification of relatives as required.
FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes
in a case, including:
 Child fatality.
 Change in caseworker or organization.
 Change in parent contact information.
 Foster care transfer to adoption.
 Change in placement.
 Temporary break from placement.
 Program or case closing.
Three of eleven closed case files reviewed lacked an action summary as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—Previous Citation FOM 722-9C
2019 Interim Inspection Report; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/5/19.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Discussed special evaluations including specific information that should and
should not be present within an evaluation including emails with DCWL or
copy and pasted contacts made by Child Protective Services staff.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Discussed and reviewed licensing rules specific to Renewal evaluation
recommendations timeframes.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were zero incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were three incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency completed special evaluations and provided information to support the
findings of non-compliance. The agency interviewed all parties necessary and
provided clear expectations for the foster homes to comply with.
12

AND
The agency has submitted zero acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
Staff interviews were conducted at the agency. Staff consistently reported feeling
supported and part of a team at VanBuren DHHS. Staff also reported all levels of
management are actively involved and encourage staff to make decisions based on
the best interest of children. During the onsite inspection, I observed staff interacting
positively. Staff discussed employee engagement activities, including peer support
groups, and employee engagement activities contributing to positive morale. Staff
valued coworkers, supervisors, program management and program director open
communication, availability and willingness to assist when needed.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued
a renewal of their regular license.
February 11, 2020
